rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Cis-trans isomerism in the polyhydroxy cyclohexane series

rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Chemical studies in the polyhydric phenol series
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Following the loss early in the Pacific war of virtually the entire natural rubber supply of the United Nations1, a vast synthetic rubber program was launched with a minimum of delay. A co-polymer of butadiene and styrene (Buna-S) had previously been discovered and showed the most promise as a satisfactory natural rubber substitute. Efforts were therefore concentrated on the exhaustive investigation of all ways of producing these monomers. One of the avenues of approach was that of high temperature vapor-phase catalysis. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A scintillation dosimeter for X-rays
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: An investigation has been made of the application of scintillating crystals in conjunction with a photomultiplier tube as a dosimeter for x-rays. The effects of varying the length, diameter and surface covering of the lucite pipe have been studied in an attempt to find the smallest practical size of the probe for a clinical dosimeter to measure dosages in body cavities or in steep gradients of x-ray intensity. Stilbene, anthracene and calcium tungstate crystals were investigated and a combination of the latter two was used to obtain a crystal response proportional to that of a Victoreen dosimeter over the range of 77 kv to 217 kv.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physics

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A study of the reaction O16(n,n)c12 by means of the Wilson cloud chamber
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Measurements have been made on the tracks of 16o disintegration stars produced by bombarding oxygen gas contained in a Wilson cloud chamber with neutrons of energies up to 22 Mev. Of the above number 141 events appear to be examples of the 0^16 (n,α) 0^12 reaction and 9 stars are believed to be examples of the 0^16 (n,α) 0^13 reaction. The remaining 10 stars could, on the basis of energy and momentum criteria, be attributed to either of the above disintegration processes but the balance of evidence is in favour of the 0^16 (n, α) 0^13 reaction. Further evidence for the O^16 (n, nα) O^12 reaction was found in the coincidence of energy levels in O^16 calculated on the basis of this reaction with known energy levels. Evidence was also obtained for the existence of the proposed 9.8 Mev. level in oxygen. The relative probabilities of the two reactions mentioned above are compared at different incident neutron energies. The apparatus and the technique of star analysis are described.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physics

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Histology of the seminiferous epithelium of the rat, hamster and monkey
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The seminiferous epithelium consists of complex associations of cells whose transformations lead to the production of the male germ cell or spermatozoon. Over a century ago, histologists and cytologists were already puzzled by the structure of this tissue. Some of the best histological works of the 1890’s were done in unraveling the complexity of this epithelium. In fact, some of the descriptions given by the workers of this time have remained classical until now. Recently, with the advent of histochemical techniques and of the electron microscope, there has been a renewed interest in the study of the seminiferous epithelium. Several important problems had indeed remained unsolved. Some of them were histological, e.g. the arrangement of the various types of cells present in the epithelium, that is spermatogonia, spermatocytes and spermatids, in a series of different combinations. Others were cytological, e.g. the complex series of changes taking place during the transformation of a spermatid into a spermatozoon. others, finally, were endocrinological, e.g. the relationship between the male hormone-secreting Leydig cell and the production of Spermatozoa by the seminiferous epithelium. The first two of these problems will be examined systematically in the present study. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Anatomy

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Causes of English colonization in America, 1550-1640
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: One of the factors which runs like a thread through the whole fabric of history is manfs inborn desire to seek the unknown, whether it be new fields of knowledge or a virgin land where never before the foot of man has trod. Abram felt the call in that distant time and in compliance with his God's request, set Jewry upon the long and arduous journey which was to lead it to the Promised Land. Down through the years, succeeding generations have also heeded the impulse that has impelled them to seek out the green, exotic fields which would guarantee them a better existence. To this endless ebb and flow of humanity, we apply the term emigration; and when these emigrants set up a community separate from the parent state, common usage has come to denote it as a colony. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: United States -- Colonization
Canada -- Colonization
Great Britain -- Colonies -- America

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The effects of alternating electrical fields on the polymerization of styrene
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The region around an electrically charged object is considered to be pervaded by an electrostatic field, the idea of a field being adopted to explain the "action at a distance of the charge. The field strength at any point is measured by the work required to move a unit charge to this point against the repulsion of the field. The field strength, or potential gradient, is commonly expressed in volts/cm. and the potential difference across the field is measured in volts. Capacity is defined by the equation QrCE where Q, is the quantity of the charge in coulombs, E is the field potential in volts and C is the capacity in farads. A common unit of capacity is the micro micro farad, i.e., 10- 12 farad.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Studies on the processing of vegetable oils
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The shortage of editle fats and oils in Canada following the outtreak of war tecame critical during the latter part of 1942. At that time an investigation was tegun in this latoratory of the production of an editle shortening from linseed oil since it is the most important domestic vegetatle oil. This research was concerned with overcoming the unpleasant odor and taste associated with this oil when it was hydrogenated. The initial work involved an investigation of the techniques at present used in the oil processing industry v/ith a view to modifying the methods already in use. From this work it tecame apparent that linolenic acid was the underlying factor responsitle for the undesiratle effects.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Agricultural Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The taxonomy of yeasts from apples
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Few reports have been published concerning the incidence of microorganisms on fruit. Indeed nothing has heretofore been published about the bacteria and yeasts that are indigenous to Canadian apples. Research about the microflora of fruit has been directed, for the most part, toward establishing the effects of preservatives on the keeping quality of fruit and fruit products. Few studies have been made, however, to determine the types and respective numbers of microorganisms initially present on fruit. There seems to be little doubt that the amount of preservative and the type of preservation used for fruit and fruit products depend to a great extent on the types of organisms initially present. For instance, the keeping quality of apple juice before it is bottled depends largely upon the initial contamination of the fruit with spoilage microorganisms [...] The present study was undertaken to isolate and classify a number of the most predominant yeasts occurring on apples grown at two widely separated places in Quebec. The study also included an investigation of the yeasts found in apple cider that was fermented and allowed to mature under natural conditions for one year, and the rate and factors affecting the rate of alcohol production by fermenting yeasts.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Bacteriology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The toxic effects of coccidiostatic sulphonamides in chickens
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The common domestic fowl harbours a number of protozoan parasites of the Genus Elmerla; the most important of these is Elmerla tenella. the cause of caecal coccldiosls in chicks. E. tenella is transmitted from host to host in the form of a resistant oocyst, which, under suitable conditions of environmental temperature and humidity, undergoes internal division, resulting in four sporocysts each containing two eporozoites. These sporulated oocysts are Infective to a new host and are swallowed with the food as a contamination. The sporozoltes are liberated in the intestine of the bird and develop in the caeca, where a number of asexual generations occur successively. This asexual multiplication consists of invasion of the epithelial cells, development into a large schlzont, segmentation into a large number of crescenWshaped merozoites, and a repetition of this process for an Indefinite number of times. This continual invasion and increasing tissue damage results in the passage of large amounts of blood from the bowel.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Parasitology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Experimental studies of the thalamo-cortical mechanisms in relation to petit mal epilepsy
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The more detailed study of the epilepsies carried out by Dr. Penfield and his co-workers has demonstrated that luany forms of epilepsy are of focal origin (Penfield and Erickson, 1941). Very often these foci are found in the cerebral cortex. The symptoms before, during and following the seizures point to definite localizations. However, certain forms of epilepsy have defied attempts at localization. Seizures consisting of generalized convulsions, without detectable aura, involving large portions of the central nervous system, are as yet difficult to understand as the outflow of a localized source or focus within the brain.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Neurology and Neurosurgery

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Heart catheterization in the investigation of congenital heart disease
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The recent advances in the surgical correction of some of the congenital heart defects have made the more accurate diagnosis of congenital heart disease a matter of considerable practical importance. The method of heart catheterization, which has been used extensively by a number of workers in the study of many cardiovascular problems, has recently been adapted to the investigation of congenital heart disease. The present report is based upon the study of 17 children with congenital heart disease in which this approach has been employed. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Cardiac catheterization
Heart -- Diseases -- Genetic aspects

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A survey of ecto- and endoparasites of the brown Norway rat Rattus Norvegicus (Erxleben, 1777) obtained essentially from the region of the "Quarry" at Macdonald College, Quebec, Canada
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Little need be said here concerning the common brown rat Rattus norvegicus. since its economic importance is so widely understood. They have, due to their migratory and prolific breeding habits, invaded and colonised all lands throughout practically the entire world. However, financial losses occasioned by these rats is relatively insignificant when the risk of disease due to their presence is considered. Plague, Rat-bite Fever, Spirochaetal Diseases, Equine Influenza, Foot-and-mouth Disease, together with various helminths and perhaps Entamoeba histolytica, are all known to be disseminated by rats. With regard to the helminths, it may act as an intermediate host for cestodes of the genus Taenia, and as a direct or indirect spreader of cestodes and nematodes; indirect infection is accomplished when the helminth has, as intermediate host, some arthropod as in the case of certain cestodes and nematodes, or some mollusc such as in the trematodes. The increased recognition of the importance of rats as reservoires of disease lends additional value to a knowledge of their parasites.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Parasites

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The dielectric constant of adsorbed ethyl chloride
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: A very wide variety of techniques has been employed in the study of the physical adsorption of vapours on solids. Since the work to be described here concerns attempts to use yet another, practically untried, technique which must be evaluated in terms of those which have been more extensively tested, it seems appropriate to discuss briefly some of the more common experimental methods, the results obtained, and some of the views generally held about the significance of the results.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The mineralogy of the St. Charles phosphatic titaniferous magnetite deposits
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The St. Charles titaniferous magnetite deposits lie on the north shore of the Saguenay River, fifteen miles downstream from Lake St. John, on lots 44-48, Bourget township, Chicoutimi County. The location of the area is shown on Fig. 1, and the relation of the apatite-rich body, to the rest of the deposit is shown on Fig. 3. Fig. 4 shows the detail of the apatite-rich bodies from which samples were obtained. The first published reference to the St. Charles deposits is by Abbe Laflanune. The exposures along the river bank were mapped by Dulieux in 1912, and further examination of the area was done in 1924 by Robinson. In 1942 and 1944 Waddington used a dip needle to show the extension of the deposits. The microtextures and mineralogy were described in 1944 by Osborne. In 1946 Dr. Jolliffe visited the area, and especially examined the apatite-rich portion. Specimens collected at that time from this locality form the basis for this study. The writer was unable to visit the area, and has had to rely largely on published reports and personal communications from Dr. A. W. Jolliffe for information on the geology of the area. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Geological Sciences

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The east zone of Giant Yellowknife Gold Mines, Limited, Northwest Territories
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Giant Yellowknife Gold Mines, Ltd., was incorporated in 1937 to develop the Giant group of claims staked two years previously on the northwest side of Yellowknife Bay, Great Slave Lake, within predominately volcanic rocks forming the basal assemblage of the Yellowknife Group (Figure 1). Preliminary exploration revealed a number of gold-bearing shear zones and irregular gold-quartz veins. From some of the latter a total of 647 ounces of gold were produced prior to 1941. In that year control of the Company was acquired by Frobisher Exploration Company, whose geologist, A.S.Dadson, advanced the suggestion that the valley of Baker Creek which crosses the claims, was underlain by a major shear zone that might be gold-bearing. Diamond drilling verified this hypothesis and ore-shoots totalling 6,390 feet have thus far been indicated within a total distance of 11,800 feet. The East zone forms one of the ore-bearing zones (Figure 2).
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Geological Sciences

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The effect on both mother and offspring of artificial egulation of the metabolic rate of pregnant and nursing guinea pigs
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Fifty-six animals were used in an experiment designed to study the effect of feeding protamone and thiouracil to guinea pigs. A modified type of oxygen consumption apparatus was described* Observations were made on the weight, oxygen consumption, feed and water intake and respiration rate of the animals during pregnancy and lactation. The outcome of pregnancy, post mortem findings and histological changes in both the mother and offspring were noted, as well as the birth weight and gains of the young. Thiouracil (40 mg./day) was without effect on the guinea pigs. The two levels of protamone used (800 ug. and 1600 ug./day) had an equal effect. Although protamone brought about an increase in oxygen consumption per unit of body weight and a decrease in rate of gain of adult female guinea pigs, no detrimental effect on either the mother or the young was observed.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Nutrition

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: On the synthesis of corticoids and spectrophotometric studies in the steroid hormone group
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: When the importance of the hormones of the adrenal cortex under conditions of stress had been established, the value of the hormones for the treatment of the injured and fatigued was recognized. The only hormone of the adrenal cortex, which is commercially available for therapeutic application, desoxycorticosterone acetate, however, has been found unsatisfactory.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The disturbances of metabolism in wounded men
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: This work represents the first comprehensive investigation of biochemical changes in military casualties as seen prior to operation in forward areas. The study includes investigation of a wide variety of blood components, data for which were previously available only as isolated findings. It has been shown that there is a close relationship between the peripheral venous oxygen saturation and the clinical condition of the patient. The use of observations on the character of the peripheral veins as a criterion in the clinical assessment of casualties, has been demonstrated to have a metabolic basis. The crucial condition of peripheral oxygen supply in desperately wounded cases has been established, and with it the reasons why blood may be of greater value than plasma in the resuscitation of these casualties. The metabolic disturbances of abdominal casualties have been found to be essentially the same as those of extremity cases. It has been shown that adequate transfusion is essential for correction of the metabolic disturbances in both extremity and abdominal cases.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physiology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Le Courrier anglais de Stendhal : ses jugements sur la politique et la litterature
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: En juin 1821, Beyle quitte brusquement Milan qu’il habité depuis sept ans. Il s’est compromis par des paroles imprudentes en matière politique et le gouvernement autrichien, le croyant affilié à la secte des Carbonari, lui intime l’ordre de vider les lieux. Stendhal se voit donc obligé d’abandonner la ville de son coeur, celle qu’il découvrit avec ravissement lors de sa première campagne dans l’armée de Napoléon, celle qui ouvrit les portes à ses premiers plaisirs, à ses premières amours, à ses jouissances artistiques en musique et en peinture, celle surtout où il rencontra la divine Métilde, qui occupa ses pensées de 1818 à 1824.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: BEYLE, MARIE HENRI, 1783-1842

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Les Anglo-Saxons dans l’oeuvre de Pierre de Coulevain
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Un lecteur au courant des oeuvres essentielles de la littérature française ne laisserait pas entrevoir une lacune considérable dans ses connaissances, s'il demandait en lisant le sujet de cette thèse, qui est Pierre de Coulevain et à quel titre mérite-t-elle une étude approfondie de ses oeuvres? Il est vrai que très peu de place lui est accordée dans la critique littéraire de son pays. Il a fallu môme des recherches opiniâtres pour établir la date exacte et le lieu de sa naissance.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: French
FAVRE DE COULEVAIN, HÉLÈNE, 1871-1913

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Studies on the metabolism of streptomyces griseus in relation to the production of streptomycin
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...] This study was undertaken to develop new media, preferably of known composition; to study the metabolism of the orgenism when grown in these media; to elucidate the mechanism of streptomycin production, and finally to develop new methods of extraction and purification of streptomycin to obtain a product of higher purity, lighter color, and lower toxicity.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Agricultural Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The origin and growth of the gonads in hydroids : origin and growth of the germ cells of Tubularia crocea with special reference to the germ-plasm theory
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The members of the class Hydrozoa are the only coelenterates that are really diploblastic (Hyman ‘4o). The general body plan, polyp and medusa alike, consists of an outer epidermis and an inner gastrodermis, separated from each other by a thin non-cellular mesolamella. The epidermis is derived from the embryonic ectoderm,while the gastrodermis is formed of the endoderm. Whether the sexual products originate from any particular layer, or whether there exists a sexual polarity between the two layers, has long attracted the attention of zoologists since the enunciation of von Baer’s germ-layer theory. Many papers have dealt with the topographical origin of the germ cells in this group of animal, the results of most of which are summarized below in chronological order.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Hydrozoa
Germ cells

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A nitrogen balance study of protein supplements in the hog ration
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: A scarcity of proteins suitable for the supplementation of animal feeds has existed for several years. Present indications are that this shortage is likely to continue, in view of an expanding livestock industry, increased consciousness of the importance of proteins on the part of feeders, and the world food situation in general. Consequently, a widespread search is being conducted for new materials to serve in this capacity, and information on their efficiency as protein supplements is important with a view to recommending their most efficient use. The most acute shortage has occurred in the case of proteins of animal and marine origin. Among the factors contributing to this situation have been government encouragement of the production of swine for export, transportation problems involved in moving fish meal from the seaboards, and increased poultry production due to a shortage of beef. In the past, animal and marine protein concentrates have been highly regarded as supplements in livestock rations, and considerable evidence was accumulated indicating their superiority over concentrates of vegetable origin. Recently, however, this evience has been questioned and it is suggested that the superiority of animal proteins may be due in part to the fact that they contain liberal amounts of minerals and vitamins in which vegetable proteins are usually deficient.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Nutrition

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Part I. ammonia-soda process applied to sodium sulphate. : Part II. The thermal decomposition of benzoyl peroxide in solvents. Part III. The homogeneous thermal decomposition of acetaldehyde
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: This investigation arose out of a problem which was presented to the Physical Chemistry Laboratoties of McGill University, and represented as being of some national importance. During the war years works had been erected in western Canada for the production of large quantities of ammonia, and it was desirable that a peacetime use for this chemicalbe found. Furthennore there are large supplies of sodiumsulphate in the Canadian west. The world-wide success ofthe ammonia-soda process applied to sodium chloride led to the inquiry as to whether the same process could be applied to sodium sulphate. Preliminary investigation indicated that the formation of sodium bicarbonate would present no difficulty, and that the chief problem would be in recovering ammonia from the ammonium sulphate formed, or in finding some method of removing It from the solutions. It was while considering this problem that the author was led to conceive of ammonia as a precipitating agent for ammonium sulphate. The object of this brief investigation was merely to establish the principles involved and to outline in a general way the proposed process.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry
